BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Along the border with Switzerland Wind slabs at elevated altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Along the border with Switzerland The more recent wind slabs can be released in isolated cases, but mostly only by large additional loads, in particular on steep shady slopes and generally in high Alpine regions. This applies in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls, as well as on wind-loaded slopes especially above approximately 2400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: In particular at elevated altitudes snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. Faceted weak layers exist in the snowpack on wind-loaded slopes. At low and intermediate altitudes only a little snow is lying. Sunshine and high temperatures gave rise to consolidation of the snowpack at low and intermediate altitudes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Gliding avalanches are the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
A moderate (level 2) danger of gliding avalanches exists, in particular on steep east, south and west facing slopes below approximately 2600 m. Gliding avalanches can be released at any time of day or night. Caution is to be exercised in areas with glide cracks.
Older wind slabs can be released in isolated cases, but mostly only by large additional loads, on extremely steep shady slopes in high Alpine regions. These places are very rare and are clearly recognisable to the trained eye.

In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the hard snow surface.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The snowpack will be stable over a wide area. The snowpack will be subject to considerable local variations at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions. As a consequence of rising temperatures and rain a crust formed on the surface. This applies in all aspects below approximately 2600 m, as well as on steep sunny slopes. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise to slight softening of the snowpack on steep sunny slopes.
Low and intermediate altitudes: The snowpack is wet all the way through and its surface has a crust that is strong in many cases.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment:
Over a wide area 5 to 10 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall on Sunday above approximately 1000 m. As a consequence of new snow and strong wind there will be only a slight increase in the avalanche danger. Fresh wind slabs require caution.

A certain danger of gliding avalanches exists.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The backcountry and freeriding conditions are mostly favourable.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The older wind slabs are easy to recognise and can be released by large loads at their margins in particular.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack will be generally well bonded.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Old wind slabs are to be evaluated with care and prudence.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The wind slabs can be released in all aspects above approximately 2400 m. Individual avalanche prone locations for dry avalanches are to be found adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. This applies in particular on steep shady slopes. Avalanches can reach medium size in isolated cases.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The wind slabs are clearly recognisable. Snow depths vary greatly above approximately 2400 m, depending on the infuence of the wind. Towards its base, the snowpack is faceted. Hardly any snow is lying below approximately 2400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The meteorological conditions will facilitate a gradual change towards better conditions.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The snowpack will be well bonded at low altitude.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The surface of the snowpack has frozen to form a strong crust.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack is well consolidated and its surface has a strong melt-freeze crust.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: In all aspects a little snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
In these regions from a snow sport perspective, insufficient snow is lying.
Even in moderately steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the icy crust.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Hardly any snow is lying at intermediate and high altitudes. The snowpack is stable and its surface has a resilient crust.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: In all aspects as well as in all altitude zones only a little snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The avalanche prone locations are rather rare. These avalanche prone locations are to be found above approximately 2600 m.
Restraint should be exercised because avalanches can sweep people along and give rise to falls.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Below approximately 2400 m from a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying. At higher altitudes snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Wind slabs are to be found especially adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls and generally at elevated altitudes. These can in isolated cases be released, mostly by large loads.
In many places there is a danger of falling on the hard snow surface.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The snowpack will be quite stable. Sunshine and high temperatures gave rise to consolidation of the snowpack in all altitude zones.
In particular at elevated altitudes snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. At low and intermediate altitudes only a little snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs are to be evaluated with care and prudence.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The wind slabs are easy to recognise and can only be released by large loads at their margins in most cases. Individual avalanche prone locations are to be found especially in extremely steep terrain at high altitude. At transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack the likelihood of avalanches being released is greater.
In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the hard snow surface.
In the afternoon as a consequence of warming during the day there will be an increase in the danger of moist and wet avalanches.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Above approximately 2200 m snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. Sunshine and high temperatures gave rise to consolidation of the snowpack at low and intermediate altitudes. At low and intermediate altitudes only a little snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: There is a danger of falling on the icy crust.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The greatest danger remains slipping on hard snow, so it is advisable to carry snow knives and crampons for the steepest sections.
The hard wind slabs can be released in isolated cases at their margins. Especially transitions into gullies and bowls places that are protected from the wind, in particular on extreme slopes at high altitude.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Snow depths vary greatly at high altitude, depending on the infuence of the wind.
Especially on steep sunny slopes only a little snow is lying. Also adjacent to ridgelines hardly any snow is lying.
As a consequence of the strong to storm force wind, a crust formed on the surface. This applies above approximately 2600 m.
The snowpack is stable and its surface has a melt-freeze crust that is strong in many cases. This applies below approximately 2600 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The backcountry touring conditions are generally favourable. Old wind slabs are to be evaluated with care and prudence.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: In all regions only a little snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snowpack will be quite stable. Snow depths vary greatly above the tree line, depending on the infuence of the wind.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the hard snow surface.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Little snow fell yesterday along the border with France.
The greatest danger remains slipping on hard snow, so it is advisable to carry snow knives and crampons for the steepest sections.
The hard wind slabs are easy to recognise and can be released in isolated cases at their margins. This applies in particular in case of a large load, especially in extremely steep terrain.
On very steep grassy slopes only isolated gliding avalanches are possible below approximately 2500 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Above approximately 2300 m a lot of snow is lying. Snow depths vary greatly at high altitude, depending on the infuence of the wind.
As a consequence of the strong to storm force wind, a crust formed on the surface. This applies above approximately 2600 m.
The snowpack is well consolidated and its surface has a melt-freeze crust that is strong in many cases. This applies below approximately 2600 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Saturday: Along the border with France, The avalanche danger will increase a little during the day.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Old wind slabs are to be evaluated with care and prudence.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The wind slabs can be released in all aspects above approximately 2400 m. Individual avalanche prone locations for dry avalanches are to be found adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. This applies in particular on steep shady slopes. Avalanches can reach medium size in isolated cases.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The wind slabs are clearly recognisable. Snow depths vary greatly above approximately 2400 m, depending on the infuence of the wind. Towards its base, the snowpack is faceted. Hardly any snow is lying below approximately 2400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The meteorological conditions will facilitate a gradual change towards better conditions.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: From a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The snowpack will be stable. The older wind slabs are unlikely to be released now.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The surface of the snowpack has frozen to form a strong crust. The snowpack will be subject to considerable local variations. Hardly any snow is lying above approximately 1800 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The snowpack will be quite stable.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Wind slabs can at their margins be released by large loads. Individual avalanche prone locations are to be found especially in extremely steep terrain at high altitude.
In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the hard snow surface.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The older wind slabs have bonded quite well with the old snowpack. Sunshine and high temperatures gave rise to increasing consolidation of the snowpack. Snow depths vary greatly at intermediate and high altitudes, depending on the infuence of the wind. In particular at low and intermediate altitudes hardly any snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: From a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The older wind slabs are unlikely to be released now.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The surface of the snowpack will only just freeze. The snowpack will be subject to considerable local variations. Hardly any snow is lying above approximately 1800 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
A certain danger of gliding avalanches exists. This applies in the regions with a lot of snow on steep east, south and west facing slopes below approximately 2600 m. Caution is to be exercised in areas with glide cracks.
Older wind slabs can be released in isolated cases, but mostly only by large additional loads, on extremely steep shady slopes in high Alpine regions. The avalanche prone locations are very rare and are easy to recognise.

In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the hard snow surface.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The snowpack will be stable over a wide area. Towards its base, the snowpack is faceted.
Snow depths vary greatly above the tree line, depending on the infuence of the wind. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to slight moistening of the snowpack on steep sunny slopes.
Low and intermediate altitudes: The snowpack is wet all the way through and its surface has a melt-freeze crust that is strong in many cases, this also applies on steep sunny slopes at high altitude.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment:
Over a wide area 5 to 10 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall on Sunday above approximately 1000 m. As a consequence of new snow and strong wind there will be only a slight increase in the avalanche danger. Fresh wind slabs require caution.

A certain danger of gliding avalanches exists.
